title: How do dogs "see" with their noses? - Alexandra Horowitz

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way dogs smell compared to humans?

options.label: B
options.text: They can only detect a limited range of scents

options.label: C
options.text: They can smell separately with each nostril, allowing them to determine the direction of the smell's source

options.label: D
options.text: They can only detect strong odors

options.label: C
options.text: Several hundred million, compared to humans' five million

options.label: A
options.text: To filter out dust and debris

options.label: B
options.text: To warm the air before it enters the lungs

options.label: C
options.text: To divide the air into two separate flows, one for breathing and one for smelling

multiple-choice.question: How do dogs exhale, and what effect does this have on their sense of smell?

options.label: A
options.text: They exhale through their mouth, which reduces their sense of smell

options.label: B
options.text: They exhale through their nose, which has no effect on their sense of smell

options.label: C
options.text: They exhale through slits at the side of their nose, creating swirls of air that help draw in new odor molecules

options.label: D
options.text: They exhale through their ears, which enhances their sense of hearing

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the vomeronasal organ in a dog's olfactory system?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect pheromones and hormones released by animals, including humans

multiple-choice.question: How does a dog's sense of smell compare to a human's in terms of sensitivity?

options.label: B
options.text: A dog's sense of smell is equally sensitive to a human's

options.label: C
options.text: A dog's sense of smell is up to 100 million times more sensitive than a human's

options.label: D
options.text: A dog's sense of smell is only slightly more sensitive than a human's

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It is processed in the same way as auditory information

options.label: C
options.text: It bypasses the thalamus and connects directly to brain structures involving emotion and instinct

options.label: D
options.text: It is processed in a slower and more deliberate manner

multiple-choice.question: How do dogs use their sense of smell to understand their environment?

options.label: A
options.text: They use it to detect only immediate threats or rewards

options.label: B
options.text: They use it to build a mental map of their surroundings

options.label: C
options.text: They use it to detect the emotional states of humans and other animals

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how dogs can use their sense of smell to help humans?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: By providing emotional support and comfort

options.label: C
options.text: By assisting with physical tasks such as opening doors

options.label: A
options.text: A dog's sense of smell is inferior to a human's

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

What is the energy-carrying molecule that cells use for various biological processes?
What is the universal phenomenon that cells must constantly keep in check to maintain their biological functions?
Why can't organisms be simply sparked back to life once they've already died?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the cells are no longer able to produce energy

options.label: B
options.text: Because the entire cell succumbs to entropy, breaking down the necessary arrangements for biological functions

options.label: C
options.text: Because the body is no longer able to move

options.label: D
options.text: Because the brain is no longer able to think

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a defibrillator in relation to an abnormally beating heart?

options.label: B
options.text: To resynchronize the muscle cells to regain their normal rhythm

options.label: C
options.text: To pump air into the lungs

options.label: D
options.text: To inject ATP into the cells

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of cryonics in relation to life and death?

options.label: B
options.text: To revive people who have been frozen at a later time when newer technology is available

options.label: C
options.text: To extend the lifespan of animals

multiple-choice.question: What is the hypothetical method of reversing cellular breakdown using nanobots?

options.label: A
options.text: By injecting ATP into the cells

options.label: B
options.text: By moving all the molecules back to their proper positions and injecting ATP into the cells

multiple-choice.question: How does the concept of life as a state of complex organization relate to death?

options.label: A
options.text: Death is the process of increasing entropy that destroys this fragile balance

options.label: B
options.text: Death is the process of decreasing entropy that maintains this balance

options.label: C
options.text: Death is the process of maintaining homeostasis

options.label: D
options.text: Death is the process of reversing aging

multiple-choice.question: What is the current understanding of the point at which someone is completely dead?

options.label: B
options.text: It is a matter of how much entropy we are currently capable of reversing

options.label: C
options.text: It is a matter of how much energy is available to the cells

options.label: D
options.text: It is a matter of how much oxygen is available to the body

title: How to create cleaner coal - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary fuel source for 40% of the world's electricity?
What is a major environmental issue caused by coal burning?
In 1952, what event occurred in London due to coal burning?

options.label: C
options.text: Heavy smog that caused thousands of deaths

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of global carbon dioxide emissions is attributed to coal?
What is the primary goal of "cleaner coal" technologies?
Why is coal a valuable energy source?
What is the process of capturing and storing carbon dioxide emissions from coal called?
How can carbon dioxide be stored after it is captured from coal emissions?
What is the name of the compound that can be used to capture carbon dioxide from coal exhaust gas?
According to the transcript, what is the most powerful force for reducing coal's environmental impact?

title: The 2,400-year search for the atom - Theresa Doud

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with first proposing that everything in the world is made up of tiny particles surrounded by empty space?
What did Democritus call the tiny particles he proposed made up everything in the world?
Who challenged Aristotelian theory by showing that common substances always broke down into the same elements in the same proportions?
What was J.J. Thompson's major discovery in 1897 that contributed to the development of atomic theory?
Who is known as the father of the nuclear age and developed the nuclear model of the atom?
What experiment led Rutherford to conclude that atoms consist largely of empty space with a dense, positively charged nucleus?

options.label: A
options.text: Shooting alpha particles at a sheet of gold foil

options.label: B
options.text: Studying the effects of X-rays on gases

multiple-choice.question: Who expanded on Rutherford's nuclear model by stipulating that electrons orbit the nucleus at fixed energies and distances?
What principle, formulated by Werner Heisenberg, states that it is impossible to determine both the exact position and speed of electrons as they move around an atom?

options.label: C
options.text: The law of conservation of energy

multiple-choice.question: What is the current model of the atom that takes into account the wave-like behavior of electrons and the uncertainty principle?
What happens to electrons as they shift between energy levels in an atom?

options.label: A
options.text: They absorb or release energy in the form of specific wavelengths of light

title: What we know (and don't know) about Ebola - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the mysterious epidemic that struck two central African towns in 1976?
What type of fever is caused by the Ebola virus?
How does the Ebola virus initially attack the human body?

options.label: B
options.text: By attacking the immune system's cells and neutralizing its responses

multiple-choice.question: What is the typical time frame for the onset of symptoms after contracting the Ebola virus?
What is the primary cause of death in Ebola victims?

options.label: B
options.text: The mounting cell deaths triggering an immune system overload

options.label: C
options.text: The lack of proper care and rehydration therapy

options.label: D
options.text: The severity of the initial symptoms

multiple-choice.question: How is the Ebola virus typically transmitted from one person to another?

options.label: B
options.text: Through bodily fluids such as saliva, blood, mucus, vomit, or feces

multiple-choice.question: Who is at the greatest risk of contracting the Ebola virus?

options.label: A
options.text: Medical workers and friends or relatives of the victims

options.label: B
options.text: People who live in close proximity to the outbreak area

options.label: C
options.text: People who have a weakened immune system

options.label: D
options.text: People who have not received proper vaccination

multiple-choice.question: What is believed to be the natural carrier of the Ebola virus?
What are some of the challenges in studying the Ebola virus?

options.label: A
options.text: Its high contagiousness and rapid spread

options.label: B
options.text: Its limited geographical range and low number of cases

options.label: C
options.text: Its unknown transmission mechanism and lack of economic incentive for research

options.label: D
options.text: Its high mortality rate and lack of effective treatment

multiple-choice.question: What are the most effective solutions to an Ebola outbreak as of 2014?

title: The hidden worlds within natural history museums - Joshua Drew

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of a natural history museum's collection is typically on display for the public?
How many specimens does the American Museum of Natural History in New York City have in its collection?
What was the cause of the mysterious decline in populations of predatory birds, such as peregrine falcons and eagles, in the 1950s?
How did the insecticide DDT affect the eggs of predatory birds?
What was the role of The Field Museum in Chicago in solving the mystery of the declining bird populations?

options.label: A
options.text: They collected data on bird migrations

options.label: C
options.text: They analyzed eggshells from their collection

options.label: D
options.text: They conducted experiments on bird behavior

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a scientific discovery made possible by natural history museum collections?
How many natural history museums are there in the world?
What is an example of how museum collections can help us understand the impact of modern threats, such as global climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: Studying the effects of pollution on marine life

options.label: B
options.text: Analyzing the changes in plant blooming times at Walden Pond

options.label: C
options.text: Tracking the migration patterns of birds

multiple-choice.question: What has been observed about the plants around Walden Pond over the past 150 years?

options.label: A
options.text: They are blooming later than they used to

options.label: B
options.text: They are blooming at the same time as they used to

options.label: C
options.text: They are blooming over three weeks earlier than they used to

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the uninterrupted record provided by museum collections?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows us to study the behavior of individual species

options.label: B
options.text: It provides a snapshot of the natural world at a single point in time

options.label: C
options.text: It shows how our world is changing over time

options.label: D
options.text: It helps us to predict future events

title: What are those floaty things in your eye? - Michael Mauser

multiple-choice.question: What is the scientific name for the phenomenon known as "floaters" in the human eye?
What is the cause of the appearance of floaters in the human eye?

options.label: B
options.text: Bits of tissue, red blood cells, or clumps of protein casting shadows on the retina

multiple-choice.question: Where are floaters suspended within the eye?
When do floaters become more visible?

options.label: B
options.text: When looking at a uniform bright surface

options.label: C
options.text: When the eye is at rest

options.label: D
options.text: When the eye is moving rapidly

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of a contracting pupil on the visibility of floaters?

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on their visibility

multiple-choice.question: What is the blue field entoptic phenomenon?

options.label: C
options.text: A visual phenomenon caused by white blood cells moving through capillaries along the retina's surface

multiple-choice.question: What causes the appearance of moving dots of light in the blue field entoptic phenomenon?

options.label: B
options.text: White blood cells moving through capillaries along the retina's surface

options.label: C
options.text: Red blood cells moving through capillaries along the retina's surface

multiple-choice.question: Why do the moving dots of light in the blue field entoptic phenomenon appear blue?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the white blood cells are blue in color

options.label: B
options.text: Because the capillaries along the retina's surface are blue in color

options.label: C
options.text: Because the space and the white blood cells are more transparent to blue light than the red blood cells

options.label: D
options.text: Because the eye is more sensitive to blue light

multiple-choice.question: What can be a sign of a more serious condition requiring immediate medical treatment?

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of the blue field entoptic phenomenon

options.label: C
options.text: Abnormally numerous or large floaters that interfere with vision

multiple-choice.question: What do entoptic phenomena, such as floaters and blue sky sprites, remind us of?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of regular eye exams

options.label: B
options.text: The complexity of the human eye

options.label: C
options.text: That what we think we see depends just as much on our biology and minds as it does on the external world

options.label: D
options.text: The fragility of the human eye

title: What does the liver do? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate weight of the liver in the human body?
What are the two main sources of blood that the liver receives?

options.label: B
options.text: Hepatic artery and hepatic portal vein

options.label: C
options.text: Pulmonary artery and hepatic portal vein

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of the tiny internal processing plants in the liver, known as lobules?

options.label: C
options.text: To sort, process, and store nutrients

multiple-choice.question: What does the liver convert carbohydrates into for the body to use as energy?
What happens to the leftover nutrients that the body doesn't immediately require?

options.label: A
options.text: They are excreted through the kidneys

options.label: B
options.text: They are stored in the liver's storage facility

options.label: D
options.text: They are sent back to the intestine

multiple-choice.question: What does the liver do with toxic substances that it detects in the blood?

options.label: A
options.text: It converts them into useful nutrients

options.label: B
options.text: It isolates them and whisks them away for excretion

options.label: C
options.text: It stores them in its storage facility

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the vital products manufactured by the liver?
What is the function of bile in the digestive system?

options.label: C
options.text: To break down fats, destroy microbes, and neutralize extra stomach acid

multiple-choice.question: Where is bile stored before it is released into the intestine?
Why is it essential to keep the liver healthy?

options.label: A
options.text: So it can produce more bile

options.label: B
options.text: So it can store more nutrients

options.label: C
options.text: So it can perform its multiple tasks efficiently and support overall bodily functions

options.label: D
options.text: So it can filter more blood

title: Could we stop an asteroid?

multiple-choice.question: What is believed to have caused the extinction of the ancient dinosaurs?

options.label: B
options.text: An asteroid impact that threw massive amounts of debris into the atmosphere

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the crater discovered in Mexico that is believed to have been caused by an asteroid impact?
What happens to an asteroid when it enters the Earth's atmosphere at high speed?

options.label: B
options.text: It explodes in an air burst

options.label: C
options.text: It lands safely on the surface

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate diameter of an asteroid that can cause significant damage to a city or county?
How can astronomers detect asteroids that are on a collision course with Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Using telescopes to look for fast-moving objects in the sky

options.label: B
options.text: Using radar to detect asteroids in the atmosphere

options.label: C
options.text: Using satellites to detect changes in the Earth's gravitational field

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the proposed spacecraft that would be used to detect and track asteroids?
How would the Sentinel spacecraft detect asteroids?

options.label: A
options.text: Using visible light to detect asteroids

options.label: B
options.text: Using infrared light to detect the heat emitted by asteroids

options.label: D
options.text: Using gravitational waves to detect asteroids

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of deflecting an asteroid that is on a collision course with Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: To change its speed by a large amount

options.label: B
options.text: To change its direction by a small amount

options.label: C
options.text: To change its speed by a small amount, about 2 mm/s

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential method for deflecting an asteroid?

options.label: A
options.text: Using a rocket to collide with the asteroid

options.label: B
options.text: Using a massive spacecraft to gravitationally tug on the asteroid

options.label: C
options.text: Using a swarm of sunlight-powered lasers to vaporize the asteroid's surface

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to deflect an asteroid that is a pile of rocks loosely held together by gravity?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is too small to deflect

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is too large to deflect

options.label: C
options.text: Because it would break apart and create a shower of rocks

options.label: D
options.text: Because it would be too expensive to deflect

title: How does cancer spread through the body? - Ivan Seah Yu Jun

multiple-choice.question: What is the process of cancer spreading across the body known as?
Which of the following is NOT one of the common routes of metastasis?
In transcoelomic spread, malignant cells penetrate the covering surfaces of cavities in the body, known as:
Which type of cancer commonly metastasizes to the liver?
According to the seed and soil theory of metastasis, cancer cells:

options.label: A
options.text: Can metastasize to any location in the body

options.label: B
options.text: Only metastasize to locations with similar characteristics

options.label: C
options.text: Die easily in the right microenvironment

multiple-choice.question: Who proposed the theory that the site of metastasis is determined by the location of the vascular and lymphatic channels which drain the primary tumor?
What is the name of the small tumors that form at a new site after cancer cells undergo proliferation?
Which of the following is a factor that plays a role in determining the success of metastasis?

options.label: B
options.text: The effectiveness of the immune system

options.label: C
options.text: The location of the primary tumor

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the modality that involves harnessing the power of the immune system to destroy migrating cancer cells?
How can the growth and activity of immune cells be stimulated to fight cancer?

options.label: B
options.text: By training immune cells to recognize cancerous cells via vaccines
